1.text: And Eliphaz the Temanite answereth and saith:—

2.text: Hath one tried a word with thee?—Thou art weary! And to keep in words who is able?

3.text: Lo, thou hast instructed many, And feeble hands thou makest strong.

4.text: The stumbling one do thy words raise up, And bowing knees thou dost strengthen.

5.text: But now, it cometh in unto thee, And thou art weary; It striketh unto thee, and thou art troubled.

6.text: Is not thy reverence thy confidence? Thy hope—the perfection of thy ways?

7.text: Remember, I pray thee, Who, being innocent, hath perished? And where have the upright been cut off?

8.text: As I have seen—ploughers of iniquity, And sowers of misery, reap it!

9.text: From the breath of God they perish, And from the spirit of His anger consumed.

10.text: The roaring of a lion, And the voice of a fierce lion, And teeth of young lions have been broken.

11.text: An old lion is perishing without prey, And the whelps of the lioness do separate.

12.text: And unto me a thing is secretly brought, And receive doth mine ear a little of it.

13.text: In thoughts from visions of the night, In the falling of deep sleep on men,

14.text: Fear hath met me, and trembling, And the multitude of my bones caused to fear.

15.text: And a spirit before my face doth pass, Stand up doth the hair of my flesh;

16.text: It standeth, and I discern not its aspect, A similitude is over-against mine eyes, Silence! and a voice I hear:

17.text: ‘Is mortal man than God more righteous? Than his Maker is a man cleaner?

18.text: Lo, in His servants He putteth no credence, Nor in His messengers setteth praise.’

19.text: Also—the inhabitants of houses of clay, (Whose foundation is in the dust, They bruise them before a moth.)

20.text: From morning to evening are beaten down, Without any regarding, for ever they perish.

21.text: Hath not their excellency been removed with them? They die, and not in wisdom!
